contentrichtext.text: Nine ships of the [[Royal Navy]] have been named '''HMS ''Warspite''''': * {{ship|English ship|Warspite|1596}} was a 29-gun [[galleon]], sometimes known as ''Warspight''. She was launched in 1596 and sold in 1649. * {{HMS|Warspite|1666}} was a 70-gun [[third-rate]] [[ship of the line]] launched in 1666. She was renamed {{HMS|Edinburgh|1721|6}} in 1721, rebuilt three times and broken up in 1771. * {{HMS|Warspite|1758}} was a [[Seventy-four (ship)|74-gun]] third rate launched in 1758. She was on harbour service from 1778, was renamed {{HMS|Arundel}} in 1800 and was broken up in 1801. * {{HMS|Warspite|1807}} was a 76-gun third rate launched in 1807 and burnt by accident in 1876. * {{HMS|Warspite|1833}} was a 120-gun [[first rate]] launched in 1833 as {{HMS|Waterloo|1833|6}}. She was renamed ''Warspite'' in 1876 after being transferred as a [[training ship]] to [[The Marine Society]], and was burnt in 1918. * {{HMS|Warspite|1884}} was an {{sclass-|Imperieuse|cruiser|0}} first-class [[armoured cruiser]] launched in 1884 and scrapped in 1905. * {{HMS|Warspite|1893}} was an {{sclass-|Astraea|cruiser|0}} protected cruiser launched in 1893 as {{HMS|Hermione|1893|6}}. She was sold in 1921, and again in 1922 to The Marine Society and was renamed ''Warspite''. She was sold for scrapping in 1940.<ref>Gardiner, p. 77</ref> * {{HMS|Warspite|03}} was a {{sclass-|Queen Elizabeth|battleship}} launched in 1913. She served in the [[First World War]] and in numerous operations in the [[Second World War]], earning the most battle honours of any Royal Navy ship. She ran aground on her way to be broken up in 1947 and was scrapped in 1950. * {{HMS|Warspite|S103}} was a {{sclass-|Valiant|submarine|0}} [[nuclear-powered]] [[submarine]] launched in 1965 and decommissioned in 1991. She is currently awaiting disposal. ==Battle honours== ''Warspite'' carries the most battle honours of any ship in the Royal Navy, and the eighth ship carries the most for any individual ship. (First) * [[Battle of Cádiz (1596)|Cadiz 1596]] (Second) * [[St. James's Day Battle|Orfordness 1666]] * [[Battle of Solebay|Sole Bay 1672]] * [[Battle of Schooneveld|Schooneveld 1673]] * [[Battle of Texel|Texel 1673]] * [[Battles of Barfleur and La Hogue|Barfleur 1692]] * [[Battle of Vélez-Málaga|Velez Malaga 1705]] * [[Battle of Cabrita point|Marbella 1705]] (Third) * [[Battle of Lagos|Lagos 1759]] * [[Battle of Quiberon Bay|Quiberon 1759]] (Eighth) * [[Battle of Jutland|Jutland 1916]] * [[Battle of the Atlantic (1939–1945)|Atlantic 1939]] * [[Battles of Narvik|Narvik 1940]] * [[Occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany|Norway 1940]] * [[Battle of Calabria|Calabria 1940]] * [[Mediterranean theatre of World War II|Mediterranean 1940-41-43]] * [[Malta Convoys|Malta Convoys 1941]] * [[Battle of Cape Matapan|Matapan 1941]] * [[Battle of Crete|Crete 1941]] * [[Allied invasion of Sicily|Sicily 1943]] * [[Allied invasion of Italy|Salerno 1943]] * [[English Channel#Second World War|English Channel 1944]] * [[Normandy Landings|Normandy 1944]] * [[Battle of Walcheren Causeway|Walcheren 1944]] * Biscay 1944 ==References== {{reflist}} * {{Colledge}} * A.E. Weightman : ''Crests and Badges of H.M. Ships'' (1957) ISBN (none) * {{cite book|title=Conway's All the World's Fighting Ships 1860-1905|editor=Gardiner, Robert |publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=Greenwich|date=1979|isbn=0-8317-0302-4}} {{Shipindex}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:HMS ''Warspite''}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Warspite, Hms}} [[Category:Royal Navy ship names]]
